Description: Fragment of a corroded iron artefact in the shape of a gently curved threaded rod stuck into a perpendicular item in the shape similar to a wing-nut . The interpretation of the item as part of a bridle-bit, as suggested by W.M.F Petrie, remains uncertain in spite of the similarity with the slightly larger item London, BM, EA 23965. If so, the rod should be interpeted as part of the cannon of the mouthpiece of the bit and the "wing-nut" as part of a shank.
Curator's comments: Considered as a possible bit in the Museum register, as fragment of a horses' bit, "riveted through cheek-pieces, as in figs. 5, 5a, 6", mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 77 § 77, p. 110. The item is similar, though smaller, to London, BM, EA 23965 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 5). Other items from Tell Dafana considered as bridle-bits: London, BM, EA 23967, 23968 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 1, 2), Cairo, EM, JE 27378 (lost), Boston, MFA 87.515 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77). Interpretation of London, BM, EA 23965, Boston, MFA, 87.516 (op. cit., p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 6), as well as London, BM, EA 23981, is more questionable.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 77 § 77, p. 110, pl. xxxvii, 5a)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.47, p.78, p.185, pl.27)
